segment.target: Security Considerations for UE-V 2.x

segment.source: Security Considerations for UE-V 2.x
segment.target: Security Considerations for UE-V 2.x

segment.source: This topic contains a brief overview of accounts and groups, log files, and other security-related considerations for Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) 2.0, 2.1, and 2.1 SP1.
segment.target: This topic contains a brief overview of accounts and groups, log files, and other security-related considerations for Microsoft User Experience Virtualization (UE-V) 2.0, 2.1, and 2.1 SP1.

segment.source: For more information, follow the links that are provided here.
segment.target: For more information, follow the links that are provided here.

segment.source: Security considerations for UE-V configuration
segment.target: Security considerations for UE-V configuration

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: When you create the settings storage share, limit the share access to users who require access.
segment.target: When you create the settings storage share, limit the share access to users who require access.

segment.source: Because settings packages might contain personal information, you should take care to protect them as well as possible.
segment.target: Because settings packages might contain personal information, you should take care to protect them as well as possible.

segment.source: In general, do the following:
segment.target: In general, do the following:

segment.source: Restrict the share to only those users who require access.
segment.target: Restrict the share to only those users who require access.

segment.source: Create a security group for users who have redirected folders on a particular share and limit access to only those users.
segment.target: Create a security group for users who have redirected folders on a particular share and limit access to only those users.

segment.source: When you create the share, hide the share by putting a $ after the share name.
segment.target: When you create the share, hide the share by putting a $ after the share name.

segment.source: This addition hides the share from casual browsers, and the share is not visible in My Network Places.
segment.target: This addition hides the share from casual browsers, and the share is not visible in My Network Places.

segment.source: Only give users the minimum amount of permissions that they must have.
segment.target: Only give users the minimum amount of permissions that they must have.

segment.source: The following tables show the required permissions.
segment.target: The following tables show the required permissions.

segment.source: Set the following share-level SMB permissions for the setting storage location folder.
segment.target: Set the following share-level SMB permissions for the setting storage location folder.

segment.target: User account

segment.target: Recommended permissions

segment.source: Use Windows Server as of Windows Server 2003 to host redirected file shares
segment.target: Use Windows Server as of Windows Server 2003 to host redirected file shares

segment.source: User settings package files contain personal information that is transferred between the client computer and the server that stores the settings packages.
segment.target: User settings package files contain personal information that is transferred between the client computer and the server that stores the settings packages.

segment.source: Because of this process, you should ensure that the data is protected while it travels over the network.
segment.target: Because of this process, you should ensure that the data is protected while it travels over the network.

segment.source: User settings data is vulnerable to these potential threats: interception of the data as it passes over the network, tampering with the data as it passes over the network, and spoofing of the server that hosts the data.
segment.target: User settings data is vulnerable to these potential threats: interception of the data as it passes over the network, tampering with the data as it passes over the network, and spoofing of the server that hosts the data.

segment.source: As of Windows Server 2003, several features of the Windows Server operating system can help secure user data:
segment.target: As of Windows Server 2003, several features of the Windows Server operating system can help secure user data:

segment.source: Kerberos - Kerberos is standard on all versions of Microsoft Windows 2000 Server and Windows Server beginning with Windows Server 2003.
segment.target: Kerberos - Kerberos is standard on all versions of Microsoft Windows 2000 Server and Windows Server beginning with Windows Server 2003.

segment.source: Kerberos ensures the highest level of security to network resources.
segment.target: Kerberos ensures the highest level of security to network resources.

segment.source: NTLM authenticates the client only; Kerberos authenticates the server and the client.
segment.target: NTLM authenticates the client only; Kerberos authenticates the server and the client.

segment.source: When NTLM is used, the client does not know whether the server is valid.
segment.target: When NTLM is used, the client does not know whether the server is valid.

segment.source: This difference is particularly important if the client exchanges personal files with the server, as is the case with Roaming User Profiles.
segment.target: This difference is particularly important if the client exchanges personal files with the server, as is the case with Roaming User Profiles.

segment.source: Kerberos provides better security than NTLM.
segment.target: Kerberos provides better security than NTLM.

segment.source: Kerberos is not available on the Microsoft Windows NT Server 4.0 or earlier operating systems.
segment.target: Kerberos is not available on the Microsoft Windows NT Server 4.0 or earlier operating systems.

segment.source: IPsec - The IP Security Protocol (IPsec) provides network-level authentication, data integrity, and encryption.
segment.target: IPsec - The IP Security Protocol (IPsec) provides network-level authentication, data integrity, and encryption.

segment.source: IPsec ensures the following:
segment.target: IPsec ensures the following:

segment.source: Roamed data is safe from data modification while data is en route.
segment.target: Roamed data is safe from data modification while data is en route.

segment.source: Roamed data is safe from interception, viewing, or copying.
segment.target: Roamed data is safe from interception, viewing, or copying.

segment.source: Roamed data is safe from access by unauthenticated parties.
segment.target: Roamed data is safe from access by unauthenticated parties.

segment.source: SMB Signing - The Server Message Block (SMB) authentication protocol supports message authentication, which prevents active message and "man-in-the-middle" attacks.
segment.target: SMB Signing - The Server Message Block (SMB) authentication protocol supports message authentication, which prevents active message and "man-in-the-middle" attacks.

segment.source: SMB signing provides this authentication by placing a digital signature into each SMB.
segment.target: SMB signing provides this authentication by placing a digital signature into each SMB.

segment.source: The digital signature is then verified by both the client and the server.
segment.target: The digital signature is then verified by both the client and the server.

segment.source: In order to use SMB signing, you must first either enable it, or you must require it on both the SMB client and the SMB server.
segment.target: In order to use SMB signing, you must first either enable it, or you must require it on both the SMB client and the SMB server.

segment.source: Note that the SMB signing imposes a performance penalty.
segment.target: Note that the SMB signing imposes a performance penalty.

segment.source: It does not consume any more network bandwidth, but it uses more CPU cycles on the client and server side.
segment.target: It does not consume any more network bandwidth, but it uses more CPU cycles on the client and server side.

segment.source: Always use the NTFS file system for volumes that hold user data
segment.target: Always use the NTFS file system for volumes that hold user data

segment.source: For the most secure configuration, configure servers that host the UE-V settings files to use the NTFS file system.
segment.target: For the most secure configuration, configure servers that host the UE-V settings files to use the NTFS file system.

segment.source: Unlike the FAT file system, NTFS supports Discretionary access control lists (DACLs) and system access control lists (SACLs).
segment.target: Unlike the FAT file system, NTFS supports Discretionary access control lists (DACLs) and system access control lists (SACLs).

segment.source: DACLs and SACLs control who can perform operations on a file and what events trigger the logging of actions that is performed on a file.
segment.target: DACLs and SACLs control who can perform operations on a file and what events trigger the logging of actions that is performed on a file.

segment.source: Do not rely on EFS to encrypt user files when they are transmitted over the network
segment.target: Do not rely on EFS to encrypt user files when they are transmitted over the network

segment.source: When you use the Encrypting File System (EFS) to encrypt files on a remote server, the encrypted data is not encrypted during transit over the network; it only becomes encrypted when it is stored on disk.
segment.target: When you use the Encrypting File System (EFS) to encrypt files on a remote server, the encrypted data is not encrypted during transit over the network; it only becomes encrypted when it is stored on disk.

segment.source: This encryption process does not apply when your system includes Internet Protocol security (IPsec) or Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning (WebDAV).
segment.target: This encryption process does not apply when your system includes Internet Protocol security (IPsec) or Web Distributed Authoring and Versioning (WebDAV).

segment.source: IPsec encrypts data while it is transported over a TCP/IP network.
segment.target: IPsec encrypts data while it is transported over a TCP/IP network.

segment.source: If the file is encrypted before it is copied or moved to a WebDAV folder on a server, it remains encrypted during the transmission and while it is stored on the server.
segment.target: If the file is encrypted before it is copied or moved to a WebDAV folder on a server, it remains encrypted during the transmission and while it is stored on the server.

segment.source: Let the UE-V Agent create folders for each user
segment.target: Let the UE-V Agent create folders for each user

segment.source: To ensure that UE-V works optimally, create only the root share on the server, and let the UE-V Agent create the folders for each user.
segment.target: To ensure that UE-V works optimally, create only the root share on the server, and let the UE-V Agent create the folders for each user.

segment.source: UE-V creates these user folders with the appropriate security.
segment.target: UE-V creates these user folders with the appropriate security.

segment.source: This permission configuration enables users to create folders for settings storage.
segment.target: This permission configuration enables users to create folders for settings storage.

segment.source: The UE-V Agent creates and secures a settings package folder while it runs in the context of the user.
segment.target: The UE-V Agent creates and secures a settings package folder while it runs in the context of the user.

segment.source: Users receive full control to their settings package folder.
segment.target: Users receive full control to their settings package folder.

segment.source: Other users do not inherit access to this folder.
segment.target: Other users do not inherit access to this folder.

segment.source: You do not have to create and secure individual user directories.
segment.target: You do not have to create and secure individual user directories.

segment.source: The agent that runs in the context of the user does it automatically.
segment.target: The agent that runs in the context of the user does it automatically.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Additional security can be configured when a Windows Server is used for the settings storage share.
segment.target: Additional security can be configured when a Windows Server is used for the settings storage share.

segment.source: UE-V can be configured to verify that either the local Administrators group or the current user is the owner of the folder where settings packages are stored.
segment.target: UE-V can be configured to verify that either the local Administrators group or the current user is the owner of the folder where settings packages are stored.

segment.source: To enable additional security, use the following command:
segment.target: To enable additional security, use the following command:

segment.source: Add the REGDWORD registry key RepositoryOwnerCheckEnabled to .
segment.target: Add the REGDWORD registry key RepositoryOwnerCheckEnabled to .

segment.source: Set the registry key value to 1.
segment.target: Set the registry key value to 1.

segment.source: When this configuration setting is in place, the UE-V Agent verifies that the local Administrators group or current user is the owner of the settings package folder.
segment.target: When this configuration setting is in place, the UE-V Agent verifies that the local Administrators group or current user is the owner of the settings package folder.

segment.source: If not, then the UE-V Agent does not grant access to the folder.
segment.target: If not, then the UE-V Agent does not grant access to the folder.

segment.source: If you must create folders for the users, ensure that you have the correct permissions set.
segment.target: If you must create folders for the users, ensure that you have the correct permissions set.

segment.source: We strongly recommend that you do not pre-create folders.
segment.target: We strongly recommend that you do not pre-create folders.

segment.source: Instead, let the UE-V Agent create the folder for the user.
segment.target: Instead, let the UE-V Agent create the folder for the user.

segment.source: Ensure correct permissions to store UE-V 2 settings in a home directory or custom directory
segment.target: Ensure correct permissions to store UE-V 2 settings in a home directory or custom directory

segment.source: If you redirect UE-V settings to a user’s home directory or a custom Active Directory (AD) directory, ensure that the permissions on the directory are set appropriately for your organization.
segment.target: If you redirect UE-V settings to a user’s home directory or a custom Active Directory (AD) directory, ensure that the permissions on the directory are set appropriately for your organization.

segment.source: Got a suggestion for UE-V?
segment.target: Got a suggestion for UE-V?

segment.source: Add or vote on suggestions here.
segment.target: Add or vote on suggestions here.

segment.source: For UE-V issues, use the UE-V TechNet Forum.
segment.target: For UE-V issues, use the UE-V TechNet Forum.
